landmark_cases.name: Rarest of Rare Doctrine
landmark_cases.case: Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court held that death penalty can be imposed only in the 'rarest of rare cases' when the alternative option of life imprisonment is unquestionably foreclosed. The Court must balance aggravating and mitigating circumstances.
key_principles: Death penalty only in rarest of rare cases
Life imprisonment is the rule, death penalty is the exception
Aggravating and mitigating circumstances must be balanced

landmark_cases.name: Basic Structure Doctrine
landmark_cases.case: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court held that while Parliament has wide powers to amend the Constitution, it cannot alter the 'basic structure' of the Constitution. This includes democracy, secularism, federalism, separation of powers, and judicial review.
key_principles: Parliament cannot destroy the basic structure of Constitution
Republican and democratic form of government
Separation of powers between legislature, executive and judiciary

landmark_cases.name: Vishaka Guidelines
landmark_cases.case: Vishaka v. State of Rajasthan
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court laid down comprehensive guidelines to prevent sexual harassment of women at workplace. These guidelines remained in force until the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013 was enacted.
key_principles: Employers duty to prevent sexual harassment
related_laws: Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013

landmark_cases.name: Right to Privacy
landmark_cases.case: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: Nine-judge bench unanimously held that Right to Privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21. Privacy is intrinsic to life and liberty. However, it is not absolute and can be restricted by reasonable restrictions.
key_principles: Privacy is a fundamental right under Article 21
Privacy includes right to informational self-determination
Can be restricted by reasonable, fair and proportionate laws
Three-fold test: Legality, legitimate aim, proportionality

landmark_cases.name: Right to Education
landmark_cases.case: Mohini Jain v. State of Karnataka
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court held that Right to Education flows from Right to Life under Article 21. Every citizen has a right to education and the State has an obligation to provide it.
key_principles: Right to education is a fundamental right
State has obligation to provide education

landmark_cases.name: Maneka Gandhi Doctrine
landmark_cases.case: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: Landmark judgment that expanded the meaning of 'personal liberty' under Article 21. Held that procedure established by law must be fair, just and reasonable. Article 21 must be read with Article 14 and 19.
key_principles: Procedure must be fair, just and reasonable
Natural justice principles must be followed

landmark_cases.name: Triple Talaq
landmark_cases.case: Shayara Bano v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court declared the practice of triple talaq (talaq-e-biddat) unconstitutional, arbitrary and violative of Article 14. Held that what is bad in theology is bad in law also.
related_laws: Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Marriage) Act, 2019

landmark_cases.name: Right to Die
landmark_cases.case: Common Cause v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court recognized living will and advance medical directive for passive euthanasia. Right to die with dignity is part of right to life under Article 21.

landmark_cases.name: Section 377 Decriminalization
landmark_cases.case: Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court decriminalized consensual homosexual acts between adults by reading down Section 377 IPC. Held that sexual orientation is natural and discrimination based on it violates fundamental rights.

landmark_cases.name: Nirbhaya Case
landmark_cases.case: Mukesh v. State (NCT of Delhi)
landmark_cases.description: Supreme Court upheld death penalty in the Delhi gang rape case. Applied the 'rarest of rare' doctrine considering the brutality and circumstances of the crime.
key_principles: Death penalty upheld for brutal crimes

landmark_cases.name: Adultery Decriminalization
landmark_cases.case: Joseph Shine v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court struck down Section 497 IPC (adultery) as unconstitutional. Held that it treats women as property of husband and violates gender equality.
key_principles: Women are not property of husband

landmark_cases.name: Anti-Defection Law
landmark_cases.case: Kihoto Hollohan v. Zachillhu
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court upheld the validity of Tenth Schedule (anti-defection law). Speaker's decision is subject to judicial review on grounds of mala fides, perversity or violation of constitutional mandate.
key_principles: Speaker's decision subject to limited judicial review

landmark_cases.name: Reservation in Promotions
landmark_cases.case: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: Landmark judgment on reservations. Upheld 50% ceiling on reservations, introduced creamy layer concept for OBCs, and held that reservation in promotions is not a fundamental right.
key_principles: No reservation in promotions as fundamental right

landmark_cases.name: Right to Information
landmark_cases.case: State of UP v. Raj Narain
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court held that right to information is implicit in right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a). Citizens have a right to know about public acts.
key_principles: Right to information is fundamental right

landmark_cases.name: Prisoners Rights
landmark_cases.case: Sunil Batra v. Delhi Administration
landmark_cases.description: Landmark judgment on prisoners' rights. Held that prisoners retain all constitutional rights except those taken away by law. Prison officials have duty to protect prisoners.
key_principles: Right to human dignity even in prison
Protection from torture and inhuman treatment

landmark_cases.name: Public Interest Litigation
landmark_cases.case: S.P. Gupta v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court relaxed the rule of locus standi and held that any member of public can maintain PIL for enforcement of public duty or protection of rights of poor and disadvantaged.
key_principles: PIL for public interest and social justice

landmark_cases.name: Environmental Protection
landmark_cases.case: M.C. Mehta v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: Series of cases establishing principles of environmental law including 'polluter pays' principle, precautionary principle, and sustainable development. Right to clean environment is part of Article 21.
key_principles: Right to clean environment under Article 21

landmark_cases.name: Dowry Death
landmark_cases.case: State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court interpreted Section 304B IPC (dowry death) and held that presumption under the section can be raised if death occurs within seven years of marriage and harassment for dowry is proved.
key_principles: Presumption of dowry death under Section 304B
Harassment for dowry must be proved

landmark_cases.name: Confession to Police
landmark_cases.case: State of Punjab v. Baldev Singh
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court held that confessional statement made to police is inadmissible under Section 25 of Evidence Act. Confession can be made only before Magistrate under Section 164 CrPC.
key_principles: Confession must be before Magistrate (Section 164 CrPC)

landmark_cases.name: Juvenile Justice
landmark_cases.case: Salil Bali v. Union of India
landmark_cases.description: The Supreme Court held that age determination of juvenile must be done at the time of commission of offense, not at the time of trial. Once found to be juvenile, must be dealt under Juvenile Justice Act.
key_principles: Age determined at time of offense
Benefits of Juvenile Justice Act applicable
